text:
Input:
Input Text: Iodine thyroid blocking (ITB) is a protective measure used to reduce the risk of developing thyroid cancer following exposure to radioactive iodine, particularly in the context of a nuclear accident. It involves administering high doses of potassium iodide to block the uptake of radioiodine by the thyroid gland. This intervention is especially important in situations where there is a release of radioiodine into the atmosphere, as it can help prevent the long-term health consequences associated with thyroid cancer. The effectiveness of ITB has been recognized, but potential adverse effects have not been systematically investigated, leading to a weak evidence base regarding its safety.

It involves administering high doses of potassium iodide to block the uptake of radioiodine by the thyroid gland. This intervention is especially important in situations where there is a release of radioiodine into the atmosphere, as it can help prevent the long-term health consequences associated with thyroid cancer. The effectiveness of ITB has been recognized, but potential adverse effects have not been systematically investigated, leading to a weak evidence base regarding its safety.
